div.l: But right faire was hir face I wil nouȝt lye
The ꝑpersoıı̄un of the toıı̄un for she was fayre
In purpos was to maken hir his hayre
Bothe of his catel and his mesuage
And straunge he made it of hir mariage
His purpos was for to bestowe hir hye
In to som worthy blood of auncetrye
For holy chirches good mot ben dispended
On holy chirche blood þat is descended
Therfore he wolde his holy blood honoure
Though þᵗat he holy chirche shulde deuoure
¶ Greet soken hath þis meller out of doute
With whete and malt of al þe land aboute
And namely þer was a grete college
Men clepen the soler halle of Caumbrigge
There was her whete and her malt ygrounde
And on a day it happed in a stounde
Syk was þe manciple on a maladye
Men wende wisly þᵗat he shulde dye
For which þis meller stal boþe mele ⁊and corn
An hundred tyme more þan biforn
For þer biforn he stal but curteisly
But now he was a þeef outrageously
For which þe wardeyn chidde ⁊and made fare
But þer of sette þe Miller nouȝt a tare
He craked bost and it was nouȝt so
Than were þere ȝonge scolers two
That dwelte in þe halle of which I seye
Testif they were ⁊and lusty for to pleye
And only for her m̉erthe and her reuerie
Vpon þe wardeyn̄ besily they crie
To ȝeue hem leue but a lytel stounde
To goon to melle and seen her corn y grounde
And hartely they dorste leye her nekke
The meller sholde not stele hem half a pekke
Of corn / ne by sleighte / ne by force hem reue
And at þe laste þe wardeyn ȝaf hem leue
Iohn highte þat oon ⁊and Aleyn highte þᵗat oþer
Of oo toun were þei born þᵗat highte Strother
